The image was published in this Facebook post on October 25, 2019.
It has been shared more than 8,500 times.
Below is a screenshot of the misleading Facebook post:

The Sinhala-language caption translates to English as: 
	“#Goodgovernance_carpets ?
	#possible to_pave them
	#Also able to_roll them ?”
“Good governance” refers to the current government coalition in Sri Lanka, elected in 2015, known as the United National Front for Good Governance (UNFGG), led by the United National Party.
The same photo was published on Facebook here and here with a similar claim.
The claim is false; the photo has circulated since 2016 in reports about a dilapidated road in Bangladesh
A reverse image search on Google for the photo in the misleading posts found this tweet published on June 24, 2016, by Bangladeshi news site BD1news.com.
চোর বাটপারির একটা সীমা আছে! দেশে এইগুলা কি হচ্ছে? pic.twitter.com/zxRMf5CN3x
The Bangla-language tweet translates to English as: “Thieves have a limit! What is happening to this country?”
A subseqent keyword search also found the photo was published here by a Twitter user who lists themselves as based in Bangladesh.
The tweet’s Bangla-language caption translates to English:  “Ah! The country really became a Singapore! The world’s first folded road ...”

আহ! দেশটা সত্যিই সিঙ্গাপুর হয়ে গেলো!
		পৃথিবীর সর্বপ্রথম ভাঁজ করা রাস্তা.....#Gay_Bangla#Gay_Bal#corruption pic.twitter.com/iUiXZuatw7
The same photo was also published on a blog here on November 24, 2017, alongside a caption it shows a road in Bangladesh.
A journalist in AFP’s Dhaka bureau analysed the photo and found it includes children wearing Bangladeshi cricket team jerseys.
The jerseys are similar to ones worn in this image by Bangladeshi cricket players during the 2015 Adelaide tour.

Below is a screenshot comparison of cricket team jerseys in the misleading image (L) and the image of some of the Bangladeshi cricket team players (R). Similarities have been highlighted by AFP in yellow:

This report published by the Dhaka Tribune on March 1, 2018, states the World Economic Forum’s Global Competitiveness Index of 2017-2018 found Bangladesh had the second worst roads in Asia. Nepal was the only Asian country ranked below Bangladesh.
The WEF report was published here. It assesses Bangladesh according to multiple factors on page 59. It was ranked 105th out of 137 countries worldwide for the quality of its roads.
The same photo has also been published alongside a false claim that it shows a road in India, as debunked here by India news site The Quint.
